       if (n < a) then
           result = 'No'

           if (mod(n,a) == 0) then
               result = 'Yes'
           else
               result = 'No'
           end if

           x = b/(b - a)  ! integer division, truncates towards zero
           if (n > x * a) then
               result = 'Yes'
           else
               low = 1
               high = x +1
               ans =1
               do while (low <= high)
                   mid = (low + high) / 2   !

Wait, the code is looking for the minimal mid where mid*a >= n? Because initially, ans is set to 1. Then when mid*a <n, they set low=mid+1. Otherwise, they set ans to mid and high to mid-1. 

Wait, the binary search here is trying to find the minimum mid such that mid*a >=n. Because when the mid*a is less than n, we need to go higher, so increasing low. But the ans gets updated to mid each time the condition is not met (when the mid*a isn't less than n). 

Once found ans, the code checks whether n is between (ans -1)*b and ans*a. If yes, then "No", else "Yes".

In Fortran, the program would have:

program codeforces_397_B
   implicit none
   integer(kind=8) :: n, a, b, low, high, mid, ans, x
   integer :: t, i
   character(len=3) :: result  ! To hold "Yes" or "No"

   read(*,*) t
   do i=1,t
       read(*,*) n, a, b
       if (n < a) then
           result = 'No'
       else if (a == b) then
           if (mod(n,a) == 0) then
               result = 'Yes'
           else
               result = 'No'
           end if
       else
           x = b/(b - a)  ! integer division, truncates towards zero
           if (n > x * a) then
               result = 'Yes'
           else
               low = 1
               high = x +1
               ans =1
               do while (low <= high)
                   mid = (low + high) / 2   ! integer division here
                   if (mid * a < n) then
                       low = mid +1
                   else
                       ans = mid
                       high = mid -1
                   end if
               end do
               ! Now check if n is outside the interval (ans-1)*b and ans*a
               ! The condition written: (n > (ans-1)*b) .AND. (n < ans*a)
               if ( (n > (ans-1)*b) .AND. (n < ans *a) ) then
                   result = 'No'
               else
                   result = 'Yes'
               end if
           end if
       end if
       write(*,*) trim(result)
   end do
end program codeforces_397_B
